Fix #5754.

data.title: GridMap - Crash when Octant size is set to 0
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Archlinux, custom-built godot version a75f5f039e31e20d985937f63cb2c8b90734160c

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Two different, seemingly related bugs occur:
1.
When the parameter "Octant Size" of a gridmap is set to 0, the editor crashes. This only happens when there are already tiles set in the GridMap.
2.
When there are no tiles set and "Octant Size" is set to 0, it is set to 1 by godot, when I add a tile after that the program also crashes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Download and open the example project linked below.
1. Set a tile in the gridmap, then set "Octant Size" to 0. It should result in a crash
2. Alternatively, set "Octant Size" to 0 before setting a tile. Godot sets it to "1". Then set a tile. This should also trigger a crash.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
A minimal example:
https://my.mixtape.moe/vvntlo.zip

data.title: ItemList tooltip does not update when Itemlist scrolls
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot Master ( 16/9/2016 )

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When mousing over a ItemList element, a tooltip will display.  If the arrow keys are used to change the selection until the ItemList scrolls, the tooltip remains static while the item under the mouse cursor stays the same.  Expected behavior is for the tooltip to change either on any key input or when the ItemList scrolls.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create an ItemList.
Population ItemList with more elements than can be displayed.
Click an item to give the ItemList focus and select that item.
From here, do not touch mouse.
Observe the tooltip.
Press up/down arrows until the ItemList scrolls.
Tooltip remains static even though mousedover element does not match tooltip. **Unexpected Behavior**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://www.dropbox.com/s/mz1gb2k0oyq0cxf/Godot%202.1%20ItemListScrolling%20bug%20demo.zip?dl=0

data.title: Fix for issue #6496: ItemList does not immediately scroll down to section
data.body:
Canged order of NOTIFICATION_DRAW to update scrollbar before scrollbar
is checked to see which list elements to display.

data.title: Adding custom OS Theme to your game (windowed only)
data.body:
If you are creating a game, or perhaps more likely game tool (perhaps a "Battle.net" type of app for your game); it would be highly relevant to add the customization option that will give you the ability to  change the window theme.

Currently, you can remove the window altogether; and kinda fake "your own window theme", but it is not possible (to my knowledge) to add transparency in the background in order to design your own. You would also have to find a way to move the window yourself. (I have not tried this yet, so I cant say for sure if this is even possible right now)

I would love to see window theme customization implemented; or at least supported (so it would be up to us to do the hard work). Some day, perhaps. :)

This is how the default Windows 8 Theme make your window (which is windowed) look like:
![](https://i.imgur.com/tvx4PCy.png)

Here are a few good examples of custom window themes that blends with the game;
**Battle.net**
![](http://i.imgur.com/lMOrw78.jpg)

**League of Legends**
![](http://i.imgur.com/RPraQfr.jpg)

data.title: Update documentation on joystick vibration.
data.body:
Added a note that long vibration durations are not recommended because of hardware limitations.

For example, my ps4 controller can only vibrate for ~3s on linux.

data.title: Image PNG flags maintenance problem
data.body:
You can set flags for individual images but those also available globally on the image loader (`filter`, `gen_mipmaps` and `repeat`) only get saved in the _.png.flags_ file if they differ,
[as per this code](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/f1e1910ae435c255745773bf37a60d798f9412fb/drivers/png/resource_saver_png.cpp#L63-L71).

I wonder if the `ImageTexture` flags should be tri-state, that is: on, off or default, the latter to let the global image loader behavior happen.

I think the global flags shouldn't affect how per-image flags are stored because you may end up losing information.

By the way (and sorry if it's in the docs but I can't find it), for textures imported to .tex files, does this work the same? If not, how does local-global flags overridance work for them?

data.title: Scene not saving while using CTRL+S when in full script view (CTRL+Shift+F11)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
v2.2.alpha.custom.build

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
~~Script~~ _Scene_ not saving using CTRL+S when in full script view (CTRL+Shift+F11)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open existing script
2. Press CTRL+Shift+F11 (to enable full script view)
3. Make changes until you see an asterisk (*) next to the script file to indicate unsaved changes
4. Press CTRL+S (This is where it goes wrong by not saving)

data.title: Kinematic move() and move_and_slide() slows down randomly with multiple objects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 (also tested on Ubuntu)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Multiple kinematic bodies using move_and_slide() cause random slow downs, it seems to happen less if the collision shapes are circles, and is the worst when using a capsule shape.

Originally Juan pointed out that if the velocity returned from using move() wasn't used with slide() or capped manually then the values might increase (like the Y value with gravity) and eventually cause slow down when the values become too large. However, in the example linked below, I'm using move_and_slide() and I'm also manually clamping the velocity values, and this problem still persists.

The problem happens more frequently with more objects, but I've had it happen in my own game project with as little as 5-6 objects, and it will drag the framerate down to single digits when it happens.

If there's enough objects, like in the example, once the problem occurs it doesn't seem to go away. If you have fewer objects (say less than 20), then the problem takes longer to appear but also goes away after a few seconds, as seen in the graph below.  

Here's what the profile graph looks like:

![profile1](https://i.imgur.com/CBDSyXZ.png)

and as you can see, when the usage spikes the fixed process count goes from 33 to 264 (when I had 33 objects)

![profile2](https://i.imgur.com/cUpgfgP.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Download the example linked below, run the profiler and then run the scene. The more objects there are, the quicker the problem appears. The example has about 26 objects, so it should happen within a few seconds of starting the scene.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[slow_kinematic.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/477045/slow_kinematic.zip)
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3292249/slow_kinematic.zip

data.title: Pixel-perfect scaling mode
data.body:
There could be a new scaling mode in godot that preserves pixel matching on the screen.
For example, when the window resizes, instead of trying to fit the viewport on it in various ways, only do it with integer steps (x1, x2, x3...).

An example of this would be the GUI of Minecraft when set to Auto. If you resize the screen, it will change its scale but only by an integer factor, thus keeping game pixels and screen pixels in sync. So you can actually tell that the viewport scale is equal to the number of pixels a "game pixel" takes on screen.

I could investigate of a way to do this as a plugin, but I wonder if this can actually make it in the engine.

WDYT?

data.title: scons detects standalone MSVC on Windows
data.body:
Under Windows, Scons is now capable of detecting and compiling with
standalone MSVC compilers (aka "Visual C++ Build Tools").
http://landinghub.visualstudio.com/visual-cpp-build-tools

Tried with version 2015, and native x86 and x64 compilers under
Windows 10 pro 64 and Windows 8.1 64, with the default Win8 SDK
provided by the "Visual C++ Build Tools" web-installer.

Follow the same compiling instructions than for compiling with Visual
Studio, except that Visual Studio is no more required.

KNOWN ISSUES :
- `methods.detect_visual_c_compiler_version()` will emit a warning message
  on computers where the `VSINSTALLDIR` environement variable is not present.
  But it should compile just fine and still automatically detects the 32 or
  64 bits according to the compiler you picked.

TODO :
~~\- try to make the `msvc_is_detected()` function available in all
script from global or import, so that it is not required to update it
several time in each scripts where it is used.~~
- eventually, update `platform/winrt/dectet.py` with function
  `methods.msvc_is_detected()` and try to compile winrt/UWP with
  these standalone compilers (if you did not select Win10 SDK when
  installing the standalone tools, you can run it again).
- update doc to make people aware about the standalone MSVC aka "Visual C++ Build Tools".
- eventually, update `methods.detect_visual_c_compiler_version()`

data.title: Gdscript: It's impossible to override _process function
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When you override `_process` method in script that's an offspring, and the ancestor have it's own implementation of `_process` both implementation will be called (first the offspring then ancestor).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Extend script with logic inside `_process` and override this method. Both implementations will be called.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[OvverrideProcess.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/475028/OvverrideProcess.zip)

data.title: EditorPlugin ability to determine/change current editor state
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It would be nice if from editor plugin there would be ability to determine various information about editor state. Some of the properties that come to my mind:
- [x] Currently active scene
- [x] Currently active script
- [x] List with all opened scripts
- [x] List with all opened scenes
- [x] Currently active tab [2D|3D|Script|Other]
- [ ] List with plugins that are enabled
- [x] Current script content
- [ ] Current cursor position in script
- [ ] Current word under the cursor in script

I also think there should be a way to change at least some of those properties, so:
- [x] Ability to open script (as far as I know already possible with inspect object api)
- [ ] Ability to close script (remove from opened scripts list)
- [x] Ability to open scene https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6495
- [ ] Ability to close scene
- [ ] Ability to set cursor position in active script

data.title: Allow signals to be connected from other objects
data.body: At the moment the only way to connect a signal to a method is within the node that emits the signal. Please enhance this so we can connect from other `Node`s as well. It will ease decoupling quite a bit. For example say I have a `game` node that emits the signal `game_over`. I don't want the `game` object to know about a `control` `overlay` node, but I want the `overlay` node to know when `game` emits the `game_over` signal. The only way to do it now is to get `overlay` inside `game` and do `connect("game_over", overlay, "_on_game_over")`. It would be really helpful if we could do something like this inside of the `overlay` node: `connect(game, "game_over", self, "_on_game_over"). In essence saying that`overlay`should observe the`game_over`signal from`game`object and trigger`_on_game_over`. This would mean that the`game`object doesn't need to know about the`overlay`.

data.title: Feature request: observable properties in gdscript
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
gdscript feature

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I find myself frequently writing accessors around properties in classes to notify outside observers when some property on a Node changes (e.g. The position of a Sprite, or any number of properties of a game entity that other consumers (like UI elements) would like to know).

It can become tedious and repetitive, but currently is worth it as you get the flexibility of information and changes flow/propagating through layers of the application naturally and in a decoupled fashion (interested consumers subscribe to data streams they're interested in), instead of being pushed by the data's owners (which can be fragile as you adapt application structure over time and the owner of some property has to keep track of who is interested in its contents over time).

It would be great if there were a pattern to abstract this away, akin to what you see with the Observable pattern in other languages/frameworks.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Currently:

```
# all of this for one observable, ouch!
signal sprite_pos_changed(new_pos)

var __sprite_pos = Vector2(0,0)
var sprite_pos = Vector2(0,0) setget sprite_pos_setter, sprite_pos_getter

func sprite_pos_setter(new_pos):
  __sprite_pos = new_pos
  emit_signal("sprite_pos_changed", new_pos)
func sprite_pos_getter():
  return __sprite_pos
```

This could be streamlined down to:

```
observable var sprite_pos = Vector2(0,0)
```

And, by convention, it would be understood that this would initialize a new user signal for the class with a specification of: `<property_name>_changed(new_val)`.

---

This is also possible, right now, by creating an Observable wrapper class to contain the value, but it makes things uglier when:

```
  var foo = self.bar
  self.bar = foo + 1
```

becomes:

```
  var foo = self.bar.get()
  self.bar.set(foo + 1)
```

Also, what's important about the Observable is that it's a data component of some larger data structure. Things like Observable wrappers just seek to atomize data in a way that can create liabilities down the road (like multiple data structures holding references to the same observable by accident, instead of a single "owner" with everyone else observing/subscripting to the data).

---

Additionally, with this pattern, you'll see it extended to collection types to fire an event when properties are added/removed to a collection (it should be noted that Array, Dictionary et al don't fire signals when their contents are modified and this is something you'd want to restrict to Nodes in the scene, anyways).

Also, once you have Observable collections, you can start modelling applications as handling streams of data over time, i.e. what's traditionally construed as "reactive programming". Just look at what's possible w/ RxPy (https://github.com/ReactiveX/RxPY)! I won't argue for/against-this as it's pretty advanced and something that requires a lot of discipline. There would be a lot of discovery to determine how it'd best fit into Godot (which is already very event driven, so these patterns would mostly be another approach to the same ideas/paradigms).

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I know everyone is busy with lots of other great features and fixes for the community. This is not a high priority change, but I feel like it would be high value.

This is something that would greatly facilitate and make clear to members of the community how applications can be structured to allow data to propagating freely to interested consumers. The observer pattern allows data-owners to focus on their own logic, as opposed to worrying about implementation details of other entities interested in their contents.

Thanks for your time!

data.title: Add WebM support
data.body:
This PR adds WebM support for Godot: WebM (simplified MKV) container, VP8 and VP9 video codecs. It uses already existing Vorbis and Opus audio codecs.

YASM is required for all x86 platforms (without it, it fallback to very slow C code with a message in console).
All unsupported configurations should fallbacks to slow C code (e.g. JavaScript or MIPS CPU) with a message in console.

Used 3rd party libraries:
- libvpx - the VP8/VP9 library,
- libsimplewebm which already contains libwebm from libvpx-1.6.0/third_party - https://github.com/zaps166/libsimplewebm

Testing:
- **Not tested platforms: Haiku, BB10**.
- Compilation-only tests: Android x86/ARMv6, JavaScript, iPhone, WinRT(x86-x64 and ARM).
- Run-time basic tests: Linux/X11 32bit/64bit (GCC, Clang), Windows 7 VS2015 32bit/64bit, Windows 7 MinGW 32bit/64bit, OSX 32bit/64bit/fat, Android ARMv7+NEON.

TODO:
- bug fixes and compilation fixes.

data.title: Vorbis: Don't compile unnecessary encoder files
data.body: I've found compilation of two unnecessary source (when working on WebM) files which are designed for encoding.

data.title: Linux/windows Joystick Bug
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Ubuntu 16.04
I'm not sure if it effects any other OS, as I only have a Linux machine.

Edit: I was able to get a hold of a machine running window 7.

Master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Joystick release events seems to not happen occasionally resulting in input events while the joystick has been released. 

Edit: Additionally once it has gotten stuck, moving the Joystick in any other direction like the opposite direction to the direction it is stuck on does not cancel out the effect. For example If it gets stuck in the right direction, moving the joystick left does not stop the right movement, and the character will continue to move right after releasing. Only moving in the effected direction cancels the effect.

I made sure it was not a bad gamepad on my end by testing two wired 360, and 5 wireless 360 game pads, and they all experience the same behaviour where direction input remains after completely releasing the joystick. 

I bisected the commit where it starts. https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/8c886b9d7a22bfacf25a5f3303c25c099abf55f9

Previous commits do not have the issue.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Map a joystick to any of the demo games. I used the 2d platformer demo, and mapped left and right movement to the joystick. It dosen't happen every time, but if you move the joystick left then quickly move right and release the joystick the moment it hits completely to the right the character will continue to move as if the joystick hasn't been released. It usually takes me two of three times before it happens. Moving the joystick in a 360 movement then releasing also causes as well.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: GDscript is slowed down by new lines and comments
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.x official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I was doing some micro benchmarking to find out best way to optimize my scripts for speed.

And I've discovered that empty lines and comments have an impact on performances.

Indeed, it is more obvious when running the script from the editor or in debug mode.
But the release mode is still affected.

**Steps to reproduce:**

you can test by yourself the minimal project below,
and/or have a direct look at the source here :
https://github.com/SuperUserNameMan/gdscript_micro_benchmarking/blob/master/gdscript_opt_test.gd#L156

basicaly, i've put 100 comments into a for loop, 100 empty lines into an other for loop, etc, and compared the delta time in ms.

In editor/debug mode :

```
100 comments : 2441 ms
100 empty lines : 2472 ms
multi line pass : 274 ms
single line pass : 222 ms
```

In release mode :

```
100 comments : 998 ms
100 empty lines : 1043 ms
multi line pass : 272 ms
single line pass : 249 ms
```

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

https://github.com/SuperUserNameMan/gdscript_micro_benchmarking
